Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Collaborative Research: Materials Engineering of Columnar and Living Liquid Crystals via Experimental Characterization, Mathematical Modeling, and Simulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Scientific exploration of soft matter resulted in numerous technological advances, such as synthesis of a super-strong polymer Kevlar, liquid crystal displays (LCDs), development of new approaches to drug delivery, electrolytes, nano-templated materials, etc. The goal of this project is to explore the remarkable ability of soft matter to form a plethora of complex, well-organized functional structures and to understand the underlying principles by which the complex soft matter structures can be designed, produced, and controlled under both equilibrium and out-of-equilibrium conditions. The focus is on a broad class of biologically-compatible orientationally-ordered materials, the so-called lyotropic chromonic liquid crystals (LCLCs) and their composites with swimming bacteria, called living liquid crystals (LLCs). Complex structures of LCLCs and LLCs span a broad range of length scales, ranging from about 1 nm (the typical molecular size), to 10 microns (the size of a swimming bacterium), and further to the macroscopic scale, at which the structure can perform a useful function, such as microfluidic mixing or delivery of microscopic cargo (such as drugs). The project is a combination of modeling and experimental efforts connected to several emerging applications. In particular, the investigations will outline the potential of using the swimming ability of bacteria in constructing microscale systems for mixing and targeted delivery of microscopic cargo. The project will also elucidate the connections between LCLC and packing of DNA in viral capsids.

The principal research objectives of this project are to explore morphogenetic complexity of the equilibrium biphasic states of LCLCs that require an implicit balance between the interfacial and bulk energy and to understand the mechanisms of coupling between the out-of-equilibrium behavior of living LCs and anisotropic interactions between the constituents, including the interplay of bacterial activity, bacterial concentration, vector field of velocities, and orientational order. These goals will be achieved through controlled experiments and theoretical modeling. In the case of an equilibrium behavior, a challenge is in finding the shapes of orientationally- and translationally-ordered structures in confined geometries, exemplified by the nuclei of the chromonic hexagonal columnar phase in the isotropic environment. The complex shapes observed in experiments need to be described through minimization of both the internal elastic bulk energy and the anisotropic surface anchoring energy. In the studies of dynamics of LLCs the challenge is in simultaneous tracking of a number of scalar, vector, and tensor fields. The project aims to advance our ability to use mathematical algorithms for fast acquisition of big data characterizing dynamic systems with complex structure. It will also enhance predictive capabilities via the development and analysis of associated mathematical models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Liquid crystals (LCs) are at the core of this grant's work. Liquid crystals are states of matter presented by materials whose molecular components consist of elongated, rod-like or plank, disk-like units (chromonic), with a tendency to align along preferred directions. Although such materials are very well-known in connection with displays, the super-strong Kevlar fiber and fiber optics devices, LC phases play a main role in the organization of soft matter systems (e.g. polymers), including biological structures (networks, such as actin in cells and in the interstitial tissue), with DNA arrangements, naturally chromonic, often following liquid crystal ordering. In this grant, we have studied both, rod-like and chromonic LCs. The latter studies include passive as well as active types (that is, they are capable of harvesting environmental resources to generate their own energy, and possibly use it to perform a task, such as particle transport).

 Intellectual merit.  Three main components run through the different themes investigated: modeling, analysis and simulation, all done in connection with laboratory experiments.

Passive LCs: Study of the solitons produced in liquid crystals under the action of AC-electric fields. The concentrated, particle-like, traveling disturbances of the orientation field occur in the so called flexoelectric LCs, able to develop polarized states, that couple with the applied AC-field, within a proper frequency range. The intended application of such traveling disturbances is to develop a new nanoparticle transport technology. The modeling of such phenomenon (and subsequent analysis) was particularly complex, since it involves accounting for multiple interactions of electric charge, dielectric, viscous, elastic and flexoelectric (polar) effects. (The work is the topic of a 2019 Ph.D dissertation and a recently accepted article).

 

Bacteria swimming in chromonic LCs. In this work, we achieved a comprehensive modeling, analysis and simulation of bacteria swimming in chromonic LCs. The system is activated by nutrients provided to the bacteria, also endowed of liquid crystal properties, that couple with those of the underlying chromonic material. We learned how to control the flow, and how certain regimes are effected, such as traveling ?channels?, across which the bacteria reverse motion, and how to achieve a preferred bacteria distribution by properly locating the nutrient source. The governing equations and their analysis are based on binary mixtures of liquid crystal components, that interact through director anchoring and friction. The results accurately reflect laboratory experiments. (The work is the topic of a 2020 Ph.D dissertation, with journal articles in preparation).

Flow of active fibers of two types: extensile microtube bundles powered by Adenosine triphosphate (ATP), and contractile actin systems. The main goal of the study is to quantify the role of geometric confinement, that in cooperation with the activity source, enables the dynamics and promotes the analog of passive flow (activated by a pressure gradient or the motion of the plates enclosing the fluid). The study of laminar flow of such systems, and in coordination with experiments, in the extensile case, quantifies the instabilities developed by increase of the active ingredient and channel geometry, and accounts for the formation of vortices and defects. Such studies are relevant to understanding the behavior of biological networks, and modeling of cancer cells in tumor development.(Two articles have resulted from this work, one published and a second one recently accepted for publication).

Formation of toroidal clusters in chromonic liquid crystals. The study of such structures was quantitatively linked to clusters of the same shape formed by DNA in free solution, but the latter being about one millionth the typical size of those made of chromonic molecules and found in laboratory experiments. This work motivated an application to modeling the organization of DNA in bacteriophage viruses (part of another project). (An article on this work is currently in press).

 

Broader impacts. Two female graduate students completed their Ph.D under this project and a student from Pharmaceutics is currently completing his masters degree in mathematics and biomedical engineering. One postdoctoral fellow was also mentored. The students had the opportunity to participate in high caliber programs (e.g. U. of Cambridge, UK) and present their work in several conference settings.

The results of the grant also have a direct impact in other areas of science. (A) The work on chromonic clustering is relevant in two main areas: (i) viral studies, for instance, regarding applications to the development of a new class of antibiotics, able to overcome the increasing bacterial resistance to the standard ones; (ii) applications to drug delivery in the pharmaceutic industry. (B) The works on active fibers may be relevant to cancer models and also to improve the understanding of biological networks. ( C) The models of solitons may inspire new nanotransport technology, already at the experimental stage. (D) The swimming bacteria studies are also relevant to nanotransport applications, as well as serving as tools in cancer modeling.
